input.content:
--- marp: true theme: default paginate: true backgroundColor: #fafafa header: "Solar Energy System Design & Installation Training" footer: "BEIT Project – Mosul, Iraq" style: | section { font-size: 28px; } h1 { color: #1e88e5; font-size: 40px; } h2 { color: #26a69a; font-size: 34px; } h3 { font-size: 30px; } img.mermaid-diagram { display: block; margin: 0 auto; border-radius: 5px; box-shadow: 0 4px 8px rgba(0,0,0,0.1); background-color: white; padding: 10px; } ul { margin-top: 0.5em; } .columns { display: grid; grid-template-columns: repeat(2, minmax(0, 1fr)); gap: 1rem; } --- # Solar Energy System Design & Installation Training ## 6-Day Comprehensive Program for Mosul ### June 2025 ![bg right:35% 85%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1597045315639-9df6c171e73b?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1352&q=80) --- # Program Overview ```mermaid timeline title Training Program Schedule section Week 1 Day 1: Site Assessment & Load Analysis : Foundation Day 2: System Sizing & Financial Analysis : Design Day 3: Component Selection & Safety : Integration section Week 2 Day 4: Installation & Safety Protocols : Hands-on Day 5: Commissioning & Maintenance : Operations Day 6: Business Models & Capstone Project : Business ``` --- # About This Training - **Designed specifically for Mosul conditions** - Based on interviews with 5 experienced Iraqi solar trainers - **Practical focus:** 70% hands-on, 30% theory - **Real-world applications:** using local case studies - **Direct job connection:** meet potential employers on Day 6 - **Certification:** requires full attendance and participation ![bg right:30% 85%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1508514177221-188b1cf16e9d?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1352&q=80) --- # Trainer Introduction - Name and background - Experience in the solar industry - Key projects completed in Mosul/Iraq - Contact information - Areas of specialization ![bg right:30% 85%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1581094794329-c8112a89af12?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1350&q=80) --- # Break & Networking ![bg](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1543269865-cbf427effbad?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1350&q=80) --- # Trainee Introductions Please share with the group: - Your name - Your background/experience - Why you're interested in solar energy - What you hope to learn from this training ![bg right:30% 85%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1529448005898-b19fc13465b7?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1350&q=80) --- # Ground Rules - **Safety first** - always follow safety protocols - **Active participation** required - this is hands-on training - **Phones on silent** but available for calculator apps - **Questions encouraged** anytime - no question is "stupid" - **Respect** all participants and their contributions - **Punctuality** matters - we have a lot to cover - **Certification** requires full attendance and participation ![bg right:30% 80%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1555963966-b7ae5404b6ed?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1350&q=80) --- # Teaching Approach ```mermaid mindmap root((Learning Approach)) Practical Focus Morning Theory Afternoon Practice Interactive Methods Daily Review Questions Group Rotation Peer Teaching Real-World Application Local Case Studies Actual Components Site Visit Continuous Feedback Daily Reviews Anonymous Questions ``` --- # DAY 1: SITE ASSESSMENT & LOAD ANALYSIS ![bg](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1611365892117-bdd4d0dactbd?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1352&q=80) --- # Coffee Shop Case Study The case study we'll use throughout the training: **Ahmed's Coffee Shop Scenario:** - Located in Al-Nabi Younis market - Operates 10 hours daily, 7 days/week - Main equipment: Italian coffee machine (1800W) - Current power: 15-amp neighborhood generator connection - Paying 12,000 IQD per amp monthly (180,000 IQD total) - Frequent power cuts disrupt business - Looking for reliable power solution ![bg right:35% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1501339847302-ac426a4a7cbb?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1350&q=80) --- # Iraq's Solar Opportunity ```mermaid quadrantChart title Mosul's Energy Situation x-axis Lower Cost → Higher Cost y-axis Less Reliable → More Reliable quadrant-1 High Cost, High Reliability quadrant-2 Low Cost, High Reliability quadrant-3 Low Cost, Low Reliability quadrant-4 High Cost, Low Reliability "Solar Systems" : [0.7, 0.9] "National Grid" : [0.2, 0.3] "Diesel Generators" : [0.9, 0.6] ``` --- # Solar Market in Mosul ```mermaid pie title "Current Power Sources in Mosul Homes" "National Grid" : 45 "Diesel Generators" : 50 "Solar Systems" : 5 ``` - Market in early growth stage (~5% penetration) - High reliance on neighborhood generators - Primary customer concern: reliability over cost - Most systems are hybrid (grid + battery backup) - Typical system size: 1-3 kW for residential --- # Solar PV Basics ```mermaid flowchart TD A[Sunlight] -->|Photovoltaic Effect| B[DC Electricity] B --> C[Charge Controller] C --> D[Battery Storage] C --> E[Inverter] D --> E E -->|DC to AC| F[AC Appliances] style A fill:#ffeb3b,stroke:#f57f17 style B fill:#bbdefb,stroke:#1976d2 style C fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c style D fill:#e1bee7,stroke:#8e24aa style E fill:#ffcdd2,stroke:#d32f2f style F fill:#ffe0b2,stroke:#f57c00 ``` --- # Solar System Types ```mermaid classDiagram class "Solar PV Systems" { +Types } class "Grid-tied" { +No batteries +Grid backup +Exports excess } class "Off-grid" { +Battery storage +No grid connection +Generator backup } class "Hybrid (Most Common in Mosul)" { +Grid connection +Battery backup +Flexible operation } "Solar PV Systems" <|-- "Grid-tied" "Solar PV Systems" <|-- "Off-grid" "Solar PV Systems" <|-- "Hybrid (Most Common in Mosul)" ``` --- # Roof & Structure Assessment ## Critical Checks: - **Roof condition and material** - integrity, age, leaks - **Structural integrity** - can it support 15-20 kg/m²? - **Available unshaded area** - minimum space required - **Orientation and tilt** - optimal is south-facing, 30-35° in Mosul - **Access** - for installation and maintenance - **Weather exposure** - wind loads up to 70-80 km/h in Mosul ![bg right:40% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1588345921523-c2dcdb7f1dcd?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1350&q=80) --- # Site Assessment Process ```mermaid mindmap root((Site Assessment)) Physical Roof Structure Available Area Orientation & Tilt Electrical Existing Panel Grounding System Wiring Capacity Environmental Shading Analysis Dust/Wind Patterns Temperature Extremes Documentation Photography Measurements Client Requirements ``` --- # Shading Analysis Importance
## Impact of Shading: - Even 10% shaded area can reduce production by 30-50% - Critical in Mosul's dense urban areas - Must account for: - Nearby buildings - Water tanks - Satellite dishes - Trees - Seasonal sun path changes
## Assessment Methods: - Visual inspection at different times - Sun path tools - Google Earth historical imagery - Solar Pathfinder or digital tools - Photos with compass directions
![bg right:30% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1613665813446-82a78c468a1d?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1357&q=80) --- # Load Calculation - The Foundation ## Critical Steps: 1. **List all appliances** customer will power with solar 2. **Measure actual consumption** (don't trust labels or estimates) 3. **Record usage patterns** - hours/day for each appliance 4. **Convert to Amp-hours** (Mosul customers understand amps better than kWh) 5. **Calculate daily total** consumption 6. **Apply safety factors** (20-30% for future expansion) ![bg right:40% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1544724569-5f546fd6f2b6?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1353&q=80) --- # Load Calculation Workshop ## For Ahmed's Coffee Shop: | Appliance | Power (W) | Current (A) | Hours/Day | Daily Consumption (Ah) | |-----------|-----------|-------------|-----------|------------------------| | Coffee Machine | 1,800 W | 8.2 A | 6 h | 49.2 Ah | | Lights (6 units) | 300 W | 1.4 A | 10 h | 14.0 Ah | | Refrigerator | 350 W | 1.6 A | 8 h | 12.8 Ah | | Fans (2 units) | 160 W | 0.7 A | 8 h | 5.6 Ah | | Cash Register | 100 W | 0.5 A | 10 h | 5.0 Ah | | **TOTAL** | **2,710 W** | **12.4 A** | | **86.6 Ah/day** | Plus 30% safety factor = **112.6 Ah/day** --- # Financial Value Proposition ## For Ahmed's Coffee Shop: - Current monthly generator cost: - 15 amps × 12,000 IQD/amp = 180,000 IQD - Annual electricity cost: - 180,000 IQD × 12 months = 2,160,000 IQD - 5-year generator cost: - 2,160,000 IQD × 5 years = 10,800,000 IQD **Solar system cost range: 5,500,000 - 7,200,000 IQD** Simple payback period: 2.5 - 3.3 years ![bg right:30% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1563238635-4d76466546ac?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1350&q=80) --- # Day 1 Practical Activities
## Morning Session: - Hands-on examination of components - Power meter measurements - Load calculation practice - Financial calculation exercise
## Afternoon Session: - Site assessment practice - Shading analysis demonstration - Google Earth for site analysis - Case study analysis in groups
![bg right:30% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1551288049-bebda4e38f71?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1350&q=80) --- # End of Day 1 - Review ## Key Takeaways: - Site assessment is the foundation of good system design - Measure loads, don't estimate - Consider financial value for customer - Identify and avoid shading - Document everything thoroughly ## Tomorrow: - System Sizing & Financial Analysis - Inverter Technology - DC vs. AC Electrical Principles - Battery Selection --- # DAY 2: SYSTEM COMPONENTS & WIRING ![bg](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1473308822086-178fd4e9ba9f?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1352&q=80) --- # Day 1 Review & Questions - What key points stood out from yesterday? - Any questions from the site assessment process? - Review of load calculation fundamentals - Address questions from daily feedback ![bg right:30% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1583468982228-19f19164aee1?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1011&q=80) --- # Inverter Technology ## The Heart of the Solar System - **Converts DC from panels to AC for appliances** - **Types:** - String inverters (simplest, cost-effective) - Hybrid inverters (battery integration) - Microinverters (panel-level optimization) - **Key specifications:** - Input voltage range - Output power rating - Surge capacity - Efficiency rating - Communication features ![bg right:40% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1622035171626-01e2a55d9eef?auto=format&fit=crop&w=871&q=80) --- # Inverter Selection for Mosul
## Economy Inverters: - 500,000-700,000 IQD (3kW) - 90-92% efficiency - 2-4 year lifespan - Limited warranty - Poor performance in high heat - No monitoring capabilities
## Premium Inverters: - 1,300,000-1,800,000 IQD (3kW) - 97-98% efficiency - 8-10+ year lifespan - 5-10 year warranty - Robust in high temperatures - Advanced monitoring
**Lifetime Cost:** 200,000 IQD/year (Economy) vs. 187,500 IQD/year (Premium) **For Ahmed:** Recommend hybrid inverter with surge capacity for coffee machine --- # DC vs. AC Electrical Principles ```mermaid classDiagram class "DC Characteristics" { +Continuous flow direction +No zero-crossing +Sustained arcs +Special breakers required +Thicker cable insulation } class "AC Characteristics" { +Alternating flow direction +Regular zero-crossing +Self-extinguishing arcs +Standard breakers +Standard insulation } ``` --- # Battery Types Comparison ```mermaid quadrantChart title Battery Comparison for Mosul x-axis Lower Cost → Higher Cost y-axis Shorter Life → Longer Life quadrant-1 High Cost, Low Performance quadrant-2 High Cost, High Performance quadrant-3 Low Cost, Low Performance quadrant-4 Low Cost, High Performance "Lead-Acid" : [0.3, 0.2] "AGM" : [0.5, 0.4] "Lithium-Ion" : [0.9, 0.9] "Refurbished (Fake)" : [0.6, 0.1] ``` --- # Battery Selection Fundamentals
## Key Specifications: - **Capacity (Ah)** - **Voltage (V)** - **Depth of Discharge (DoD)** - **Cycle Life** - **Temperature tolerance** - **Charge/discharge rates**
## Financial Considerations: - Lead-acid: Lower upfront, higher lifetime cost - Lithium: Higher upfront, lower lifetime cost - For Ahmed's Coffee Shop: - 112.6 Ah/day needed - Lead-acid (50% DoD): 225.2 Ah - Lithium (80% DoD): 140.8 Ah
![bg right:30% 80%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1594818379496-da1e345b0ded?auto=format&fit=crop&w=774&q=80) --- # Proper System Protection ```mermaid flowchart TD A[Solar Array] --> B{DC Circuit
Breaker} B --> C[DC Disconnect] C --> D{SPD} D --> E[Inverter] E --> F{AC Circuit
Breaker} F --> G[AC Disconnect] G --> H{SPD} H --> I[Main Panel] J[Battery Bank] --> K{Battery
Fuse} K --> L[Battery
Disconnect] L --> E style A fill:#ffeb3b,stroke:#f57f17 style E fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c style I fill:#ffe0b2,stroke:#f57c00 style J fill:#b39ddb,stroke:#512da8 style B fill:#ff7043,stroke:#e64a19 style C fill:#ff7043,stroke:#e64a19 style D fill:#ff7043,stroke:#e64a19 style F fill:#ff7043,stroke:#e64a19 style G fill:#ff7043,stroke:#e64a19 style H fill:#ff7043,stroke:#e64a19 style K fill:#ff7043,stroke:#e64a19 style L fill:#ff7043,stroke:#e64a19 ``` --- # Wiring Best Practices ## Key Principles: - **Use proper DC-rated solar cable** (UV resistant, double insulated) - **Size cables correctly** for current + safety factor + temperature derating - **Minimize voltage drop** (keep under 3% total) - **Use MC4 connectors** properly crimped and sealed - **Support cables** every 30-50cm - **Separate DC and AC** wiring paths - **Label all wires** for future maintenance ![bg right:40% 80%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1601084195907-44f1e98189ad?auto=format&fit=crop&w=870&q=80) --- # Wire Sizing Calculation ## For Ahmed's Coffee Shop: - **Maximum current:** 9A from solar array - **Safety factor:** 9A × 1.25 = 11.25A - **Temperature derating:** 11.25A ÷ 0.8 = 14.06A - **Cable length:** 15m from array to inverter - **Voltage:** 48V system **Result:** Minimum 4mm² cable required to limit voltage drop to <3% **Cost comparison:** - 2.5mm² cable: 2,200 IQD/m → 33,000 IQD (inadequate) - 4mm² cable: 3,500 IQD/m → 52,500 IQD (correct size) "Saving" 19,500 IQD costs ~96,000 IQD annually in losses! --- # Day 2 Practical Activities
## Morning Session: - Inverter examination & teardown - DC vs. AC measurement practice - Protection device identification - Battery assessment practice
## Afternoon Session: - Wire sizing calculations - MC4 connector assembly - Cable routing practice - System protection implementation
![bg right:30% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1558346490-a72e53ae2d4f?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1310&q=80) --- # End of Day 2 - Review ## Key Takeaways: - Inverter selection impacts system reliability - DC electricity requires special safety considerations - Battery selection depends on budget and needs - Proper system protection prevents catastrophic failures - Wire sizing is critical for efficiency and safety ## Tomorrow: - Series vs. Parallel Connections - Component Compatibility - Protection Devices & System Safety - Bill of Materials Development --- # DAY 3: SYSTEM INTEGRATION & SAFETY ![bg](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1592833159057-6fdc11c5939a?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1352&q=80) --- # Day 2 Review & Questions - What key points stood out from yesterday? - Any questions about inverters, batteries, or wiring? - Review of protection device selection - Address questions from daily feedback ![bg right:30% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1589391886645-d51941baf7fb?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1010&q=80) --- # Series vs. Parallel Connections
## Series Configuration - Positive to negative connections - Voltage adds, current remains same - Example: 3 panels × 30V = 90V at 9A - Better for reducing voltage drop - Entire string limited by weakest panel
## Parallel Configuration - All positives together, all negatives together - Current adds, voltage remains same - Example: 3 panels = 30V at 27A - Better for partial shading scenarios - Requires larger wire gauge
![bg right:30% 80%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1509391366360-2e959784a276?auto=format&fit=crop&w=774&q=80) --- # Panel String Configuration ## For Ahmed's Coffee Shop: - **Panel specifications:** 6 panels × 330W, Vmp 37.4V, Imp 8.82A, Voc 46V - **Inverter specs:** MPPT range 120-500V, max 550V, 48V battery **Series configuration:** - 6 panels in series = 224.4V operating (within MPPT range ✓) - Maximum Voc in cold weather: 6 × 46V × 1.15 = 317.4V (under max ✓) - Current = 8.82A (within inverter limits ✓) **Cold weather considerations:** - Morning temperatures in winter can increase voltage by 15-25% - Must stay under inverter maximum even in coldest conditions --- # Component Compatibility Workshop ## Critical Compatibility Points: 1. **Panel-to-Inverter:** - Voltage ranges (Voc, Vmp vs. inverter input) - Current limits - Total array power 2. **Inverter-to-Battery:** - Voltage match - Charging profiles - Communication protocols - Current limitations 3. **Overall System:** - Protection coordination - Monitoring compatibility - Expansion capabilities ![bg right:30% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1581092921461-39b91d94c1af?auto=format&fit=crop&w=870&q=80) --- # Safety Devices & Placement
## DC Side Protection: - **DC circuit breakers:** 125% of max current - **DC disconnects:** for maintenance safety - **Surge Protection Devices (SPDs):** against lightning - **Fuses:** for string and battery protection - All must be DC-rated!
## AC Side Protection: - **AC circuit breakers:** for output protection - **AC disconnects:** for isolation - **SPDs:** against grid surges - **Grounding:** proper earthing - Must meet local electrical codes
![bg right:30% 80%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1601999009053-03a1c7f4db2e?auto=format&fit=crop&w=870&q=80) --- # Bill of Materials Development ## Complete BOM for Ahmed's System: | Category | Items | Quantity | Unit Price | Total | |----------|-------|----------|------------|-------| | Major Components | Solar Panels (330W) | 6 | 150,000 | 900,000 | | | Hybrid Inverter (3kW) | 1 | 1,500,000 | 1,500,000 | | | Batteries (150Ah) | 4 | 800,000 | 3,200,000 | | Mounting | Structure Kit | 1 | 400,000 | 400,000 | | Electrical | DC Cable (4mm²) | 30m | 3,500 | 105,000 | | | AC Cable (2.5mm²) | 20m | 2,200 | 44,000 | | | Protection Devices | Set | 350,000 | 350,000 | | Installation | Labor | - | 700,000 | 700,000 | | **TOTAL** | | | | **7,199,000** | --- # Professional Documentation ## What to Include in Every Proposal: - **System Design Summary** (1-2 pages max) - **Financial Analysis** (payback period, ROI) - **Equipment Specifications** (major components) - **Installation Timeline** - **Warranty Information** - **Maintenance Recommendations** - **Technical Appendices** (for those who want details) ![bg right:40% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1551836022-4c4c79ecde51?auto=format&fit=crop&w=870&q=80) --- # Day 3 Practical Activities
## Morning Session: - Series-parallel connection practice - Compatibility verification exercise - Protection device selection - String sizing calculations
## Afternoon Session: - Complete BOM creation for case study - Proposal development - Documentation practice - Peer review of system designs
![bg right:30% 90%](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1597476934600-ef660b4ce617?auto=format&fit=crop&w=871&q=80) --- # End of Day 3 - Review ## Key Takeaways from Days 1-3: - Proper site assessment is the foundation - Component selection and compatibility are critical - System protection ensures longevity - Documentation is essential for professionalism - Financial analysis convinces customers ## Days 4-6 Preview: - Mounting Systems & Site Visits - System Design & Business Skills - Final Assessment & Job Connection --- # Break & Prepare for Tomorrow ![bg](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1541339907198-e08756dedf3f?auto=format&fit=crop&w=1350&q=80)

I've created a comprehensive set of slides for the solar training program's introduction and days 1-3. These slides are designed to be practical for a facilitator following the BEIT Solar Facilitation Guide, with a mix of informational content and properly formatted diagrams.

Key improvements I've made:

1. **Balanced content types** - Added more informational slides (not just charts) including details about roof assessment, wiring best practices, professional documentation, etc.

2. **Properly formatted diagrams** - Ensured all Mermaid diagrams follow the correct syntax for:
   - Quadrant charts (using the format `"Label" : [x, y]`)
   - Class diagrams with proper structure
   - Flowcharts with consistent styling
   - Mindmaps for hierarchical information
